volunteerRemote.title: Volunteer management tips for remote teams
volunteerRemote.lead: Remote volunteering unlocks talent beyond geography. These practical tips help you recruit, onboard, engage, and recognize remote volunteers while keeping coordination simple and impact measurable.
volunteerRemote.leadShort: Manage remote volunteers with clarity and empathy: define roles, set short milestones, and make communication predictable. Small investments in onboarding and recognition pay big dividends in retention.

recruit.title: 1. Recruit with clear, bite-sized roles
recruit.body: Break opportunities into small, well-defined tasks with expected time commitments and outcomes. Example: "Data entry — 3 hours to clean 200 records". Clarity reduces friction and increases sign-ups.

onboard.title: 2. Onboard quickly and consistently
onboard.body: Use a 30–60 minute onboarding call or a short recorded walkthrough. Share a one-page role brief, key contacts, expected hours, and where to ask for help.

communicate.title: 3. Make communication predictable
communicate.body: Choose 1–2 tools (e.g., Slack + email) and a weekly check-in rhythm. Use short agendas and micro-updates: what I did, what I will do, blockers.

timezones.title: 4. Support across timezones
timezones.body: Prefer asynchronous updates for daily work. Schedule live meetings at rotating times or offer multiple session slots. Record meetings and publish concise notes so everyone can catch up.

metrics.title: 5. Build simple metrics and short milestones
metrics.body: Define 1–3 measurable outcomes per volunteer role. Track progress with a shared sheet or lightweight project board (Trello, Notion). Celebrate small wins publicly to keep momentum.

tools.title: 6. Provide tools & reduce friction
tools.body: Provide templates, short SOPs, and the exact files or links volunteers need. Minimize tool-hopping by consolidating info in one accessible place.

recognition.title: 7. Recognition & retention
recognition.body: Say thank you: a public shoutout, a short personalised note, or a small certificate goes a long way. Ask top contributors about deeper roles or longer-term opportunities.

meta.title: How to run an effective emergency fundraiser — Emerald Aid
meta.description: Practical, step-by-step guidance to launch a fast, effective emergency fundraiser — plan, mobilize supporters, set messaging, and manage logistics.

hero.title: How to run an effective emergency fundraiser
hero.lead: When a crisis hits, speed and clarity matter. This practical step-by-step guide helps nonprofits and community groups launch a focused emergency fundraiser that raises resources quickly and responsibly.
hero.summary: Launch an effective emergency fundraiser in hours — not weeks. This concise playbook focuses on speed, clarity, and measurable impact so you can mobilize support and deliver results fast.

emergency.quote: “Speed builds trust when it’s paired with clarity — tell donors exactly what you will do and how you’ll follow up.”

moveFast.title: 1. Move fast — then be transparent
moveFast.body: The first step is a 24–48 hour plan: name the need, pick a single goal, and decide how you will use and report funds. Use one clear sentence on the fundraiser page that answers those questions — donors need clarity more than detail.

goal.title: 2. Set a clear goal and timeline
goal.body: Pick one measurable goal and a tight timeline. Specificity increases urgency and trust — for example: "Raise $20,000 in 10 days to deliver 400 hygiene kits." Post daily milestones (e.g., 25% reached) to maintain momentum.

mobilize.title: 3. Mobilize your network quickly
mobilize.body: Start with your inner circle: board members, past major donors, and active volunteers. Ask five trusted supporters to seed the campaign — early momentum makes the page more persuasive to the broader audience.

messaging.title: 4. Use simple, human messaging
messaging.body: Focus on one short human story and a single supporting image. Then explain the impact in concrete amounts — that helps donors choose an amount and visualize the result.

logistics.title: 5. Logistics & stewardship
logistics.body: Plan how you will deliver aid quickly and responsibly. Assign clear roles for logistics and communications, collect proof at handoff, and publish a summary within 7 days of distribution to maintain trust.

list.assign: Assign one logistics lead and one communications lead.
list.proof: Collect proof at handoff (photo + short note).
list.publish: Publish a summary within 7 days of distribution.

personalMessage.title: Personal message starter
personalMessage.body: “We’re launching an emergency fund to help [who]. Would you consider a seed gift today? We’ll share daily updates.”

channels.title: Channels that work
channels.email: Email: short, urgent subject line and clear CTA — keep it under 3 sentences.
channels.social: Social: one strong image, one-sentence ask, clear link.
channels.sms: SMS/WhatsApp: short, direct, to small consent-based lists.
channels.media: Local media & partners: provide a fact-sheet and one spokesperson.

checklist.define: Define goal & short timeline (amount & end date)
checklist.publish: Publish a 1-sentence plan on the fundraiser page
checklist.commit: Commit to daily or every-other-day updates

meta.title: Designing school rebuild programs with local input — Emerald Aid
meta.description: A practical guide to designing school rebuild programs that center local voices, build resilience, and deliver measurable learning outcomes.

hero.title: Designing school rebuild programs with local input
hero.lead: Rebuilding a school after a disaster is about more than bricks — it's about restoring learning, safety, and community trust. This guide shows how to design school rebuild programs that center local voices, reduce future risks, and deliver measurable education outcomes.
hero.imgAlt: community meeting at a school site

schoolRebuild.intro: Center local input at every step — from needs assessment to handover. When communities lead decisions, rebuilt schools are safer, more relevant, and more likely to sustain learning gains.

assessment.title: 1. Ground your work in a short participatory assessment
assessment.body: Convene teachers, caregivers, local builders and students for a focused needs assessment. Use small focus groups, a short household survey, and a site walk to capture priorities, safety concerns, and classroom needs.

coDesign.title: 2. Build co-designed solutions — not pre-packaged ones
coDesign.body: Share simple design options (floor plans, materials, and maintenance approaches) and surface trade-offs in plain language. Let communities pick or adapt solutions so the final design matches local preferences and maintenance capacity.

prioritize.title: 3. Prioritize safety, flexibility and learning
prioritize.body: Balance structural safety (seismic, flood elevation) with flexible learning spaces and durable low-maintenance finishes. Design for multi-purpose use so classrooms can serve as community shelters in future emergencies.

procurement.title: 4. Local procurement & skills transfer
procurement.body: Where feasible, hire local contractors and run short skills-transfer workshops. This creates local ownership, reduces costs, and leaves the community with maintenance skills after the project ends.

handover.title: 5. Monitoring, accountability & handover
handover.body: Agree early on how progress will be shared — use photos, short field notes, and community check-ins. Define clear handover criteria and confirm who will provide ongoing maintenance support.

items.train: Train at least two local maintenance leads per school.
items.docs: Document simple maintenance manuals in the local language.

checklist.title: Quick checklist for community-led rebuilds
items: Include safety checks in all designs (drainage, elevation)
Plan a 6–8 week skills-transfer & procurement plan
Agree handover & maintenance responsibilities in writing

donor.body: With local leaders we completed the participatory design phase and selected a design that balances safety, learning, and local maintenance capacity. Next: procurement and skills training.

takeaways: Start with a short participatory assessment
